topic.title: Response Time

body.p: The response to request latency must be able to accommodate the highest bandwidth channel. A response time of 40ns will cope with any channel bandwidth. If fewer than 4 framers are in operation then longer response times can be tolerated. The maximum bandwidth of overhead the OHP can support is four framers worth each running 600G of bandwidth.
The Extraction packet (req+ data, or only data) is 349 bytes, which is 0.28 us on the XGMII interface for transfers including 12-byte IPG.
The Request only packet is 64 bytes which is 0.0608 us on the XGMII interface for transfers including 12-byte IPG.
The insertion packet is 399 bytes which is 0.32 us on the XGMII interface for transfers including 12-byte IPG.

Since the insertion packet is larger than the extraction packet or the request-only packet, the FPGA needs to store the requests coming from the extraction stream into a FIFO. The minimum depth of the request FIFO needs to be approximately 2 * the total number of channels on the OHP instance 2 * (190 + 190 + 6 + 6) = 784 bytes. The OHP instance one requires 2 * (6 + 190 + 126 + 6) = 656 bytes.
Internally, the insertion data is stored in an internal per-channel FIFO prior to being inserted into the ODU_TFRM. The size of the FIFO scales according to the rate.

The request packets (TX_FI sent) center this insertion FIFO. For instance, in an ODU0 if this FIFO is less than 8 frames of data, a request packet is queued to be sent to the external FPGA. For all ODUk rates, the center is around where the TX_FI is set (i.e., half-way in the FIFO).

For a single ODU0, the user needs to optimize the turnaround latency such that each channel can be serviced if there is a continuous burst of requests. The recommendation is to ensure the insertion pipe is always full whenever the request FIFO in the external FPGA has data.

The below figure shows how the request and insertion interfaces can run if the external FPGA uses 40 us to prime the initial pipe (not that it is only initial pipe; but this ensures the pipe is always full).

The figure above shows that the insertion logic in the external device can take up to 40 us to prime the insertion upon receiving the first request, but after receiving the first request, consecutive insertions need to happen back-to-back without delays such that it always has the insertion SGMII full. The re-priming of the insertion pipe absorbs another 40 us as shown above at the break point T1 in the diagram on the second set of request cycles.
For the 190-channel framers (single response time chosen based on fastest channel):

li.p: To support ODUflex channels of > 100GHz, a turnaround time of at most (45*600G/channel bandwidth) us is recommended.
To support FlexO, a turnaround time of at most 140us is recommended, due to FlexOâ€™s smaller multiframe size.
Otherwise a turnaround time of 270us is sufficient for all other channel types (FlexE, ODUk, ODUCn).
A turnaround time of at most 140us is recommended for all channel types.

body.p: Note : The 40 us priming latency is just an example. The hard specification is the overall turnaround time per ODUk channel, which is around 800 us. With multiple ODUks, the time would need to be managed.
